body.p: Some commentators suggested that property held for sale in the ordinary course of business should be treated as investment property rather than as inventories (covered by IAS 2). They argued that:

li.p: it is difficult to distinguish property held for sale in the ordinary course of business from property held for capital appreciation; and

it is illogical to require a fair value model for land and buildings held for long‑term capital appreciation (investment property) when a cost model is still used for land and buildings held for short‑term sale in the ordinary course of business (inventories).
